mesh4d.field.Trans_Nonrigid#

class mesh4d.field.Trans_Nonrigid(source_obj: None | Type[Obj3d] = None, target_obj: None | Type[Obj3d] = None, **kwargs)[source]#

Bases: Trans

The non-rigid transformation, under which points in different locations may be transformed in different directions and distances. Such an idea can be expressed in the form of \(\mathcal{T}\):

\[\mathcal{T}(\boldsymbol S) = \boldsymbol S + \boldsymbol T\]

where \(\boldsymbol S \in \mathbb R^{N \times 3}\) and \(\boldsymbol T \in \mathbb R^{N \times 3}\) stand for the original point cloud and the translation matrix, all stored in the form of \(N \times 3\) matrix.

Note

Class Attributes

self.source_points

The source points \(\boldsymbol S \in \mathbb R^{N \times 3}\) stored in (N, 3) numpy.array.

self.deform_points

The deformed points \(\boldsymbol S + \boldsymbol T \in \mathbb R^{N \times 3}\) stored in (N, 3) numpy.array.

self.disp

The displacement matrix \(\boldsymbol T \in \mathbb R^{N \times 3}\) stored in (N, 3) numpy.array.

self.search_tree

scipy.spatial.KDTree of self.source_points, used for acquired the nearest point for a given point from self.source_points.

See also

scipy.spatial.KDTree

scipy.spatial.KDTree.query

Attention

After initialisation, the registration method regist() must be called to estimate the non-rigid transformation between the source and target point cloud.

Example

After loading and registration, the rigid transformation parameters can then be accessed, including the scaling rate, the rotation matrix, and the translation vector:

from mesh4d import obj3d, field

o3_1 = obj3d.Obj3d('data/6kmh_softbra_8markers_1/speed_6km_soft_bra.000001.obj')
o3_2 = obj3d.Obj3d('data/6kmh_softbra_8markers_1/speed_6km_soft_bra.000002.obj')

trans = field.Trans_Nonrigid(o3_1, o3_2)
trans.regist()
print(trans.deform_points, trans.disp)
__init__(source_obj: None | Type[Obj3d] = None, target_obj: None | Type[Obj3d] = None, **kwargs)#

Methods

Add the visualisation of current object to a pyvista.Plotter scene.

Return the inverted non-rigid transformation.

regist([k_nbr])

Align every point from the source object to the nearest point in the target object and use it a this point's displacement.

Implement the transformation to the key points object.

Illustrate the estimated transformation.
regist(k_nbr: int = 3, **kwargs)[source]#

Align every point from the source object to the nearest point in the target object and use it a this point’s displacement.

Parameters:

k_nbr – the number of nearest neighbors to be involved to calculate the average movement as the movement of the input points.

shift_points(points: array, k_nbr: int = 3) → array[source]#

Implement the transformation to set of points.

To apply proper transformation to an arbitrary point \(\boldsymbol x\):

  • Find the closest point \(\boldsymbol s_{\boldsymbol x}\) and its displacement \(\boldsymbol t_{\boldsymbol x}\).

  • Use \(\boldsymbol t_{\boldsymbol x}\) as \(\boldsymbol x\)’s displacement: \(\boldsymbol x' = \boldsymbol x + \boldsymbol t_{\boldsymbol x}\)

Warning

This logic may be replaced by better scheme in future development.

Parameters:

  • points – \(N\) points in 3D space that we want to implement the transformation on. Stored in a (N, 3) numpy.array.

  • k_nbr – the number of nearest neighbors to be involved to calculate the average movement as the movement of the input points

Returns:

(N, 3) numpy.array stores the points after transformation.

Return type:

numpy.array

add_to_scene(scene: Plotter, location: array = array([0, 0, 0]), **kwargs) → Plotter[source]#

Add the visualisation of current object to a pyvista.Plotter scene.

Parameters:

  • scene – pyvista.Plotter scene to add the visualisation.

  • location – the displace location represented in a (3, ) numpy.array.

  • **kwargs –

    other visualisation parameters.

    See also

    pyvista.Plotter.add_mesh pyvista.Plotter.add_points

Returns:

pyvista.Plotter scene added the visualisation.

Return type:

pyvista.Plotter

invert()[source]#

Return the inverted non-rigid transformation.

Note

The non-rigid transformation is formulated as:

\[\boldsymbol Y = \boldsymbol S + \boldsymbol T\]

Therefore, the inverted transformation should be:

\[\boldsymbol S = \boldsymbol Y - \boldsymbol T\]
